prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author and their girlfriend live together. He pays all the bills because she works part-time. There was an incident where he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She had a negative reaction, which made him upset. Now he's considering making her pay some bills, even though he admits she can't cover a lot, just for principle.

First, I need to consider the dynamics of their relationship. They live together, so splitting expenses is a common topic. The author has been covering everything, maybe out of generosity or because he assumed that's how it would be. But the girlfriend is working part-time, which might mean her income is limited. So, maybe there's an understanding that he pays the bulk, and she contributes in other ways.

The key point here is the single incident where he asked her to pay for takeout. He felt she reacted in a negative, almost disgusted way. That could be because she's used to him handling all expenses and felt it was unfair or unexpected. Maybe she's been saving up or had other expenses, and even $40 was a strain. Her reaction might not be about the money itself but the principle of being asked to contribute when she's used to not having to.

From the author's perspective, he's frustrated because he's been paying everything and feels that this incident highlighted a need for her to start contributing, even if it's small. He's making this about principle, which is a valid point. But is it fair to make her pay more because of one incident? Especially if her income is limited.

The question is whether the author is in the wrong. If he's been paying all the bills up to now, maybe there was an implied agreement or understanding. Changing that suddenly after one incident could be seen as unfair, especially if her financial situation hasn't significantly improved. On the other hand, if he feels that contributing to shared expenses is important, then it's reasonable to discuss splitting some costs, but doing so abruptly after a single incident might not be the best approach.

Also, the way he's framing it seems a bit entitled. He mentions that it was "some fucking take out" implying that $40 isn't a big deal, but doesn't consider that her part-time job might mean that $40 is a significant portion of her income. The fact that she had a strong reaction suggests that maybe he's been taking her for granted. Making her pay more just because of one incident could be seen as punitive, which isn't fair. Instead, a conversation about how expenses are handled going forward would be healthier for the relationship.

So, the author is in the wrong because he's reacting disproportionately to a single incident and not considering her financial situation. He should have had an open discussion about splitting expenses rather than using one event as a catalyst to change their financial arrangement. This could lead to resentment on her part if she's not ready or able to take on more financial responsibility.
